sentences.sentence: Disclosing info won't benefit super membersThe opinion piece by David Gallagher and Peter Swan ("Why making big super disclose its assets is best global practice", October 26) is factually incorrect.It argues that the government's proposal to make industry super funds disclose commercially sensitive valuations of unlisted assets is consistent with global best practice, exemplified by the US Securities Exchange Commission's portfolio holdings disclosure rules.

However, the SEC requires institutional investors to disclose only listed assets, not unlisted assets.The main beneficiaries of the government's proposal would be the likes of private equity funds and foreign investors looking to exploit the private information of industry super fund members.

The losers would be millions of working Australians who rely on industry super fund trustees to protect and grow their retirement nest eggs.The government has clearly recognised the risks of such disclosures and sought an exemption for the Future Fund from the Freedom of Information Act on the basis it could risk the value of its investment portfolio.Quite rightly, the last thing the Future Fund wants is the investors to whom it might want to sell an asset knowing exactly how much the Future Fund itself thinks that asset is worth.

IFM Investors and industry super funds support disclosures that will help members better understand where their retirement savings are invested, and have suggested a range of solutions to the government.
To its credit, the government has consulted widely and it is hoped that a balanced outcome is achievable.
As an aside, the article describes industry super funds as "union-dominated funds".

They are, in fact, jointly governed by employer associations and unions.David NealChief executive, IFM InvestorsMelbourne, VicDoesn't ethics apply to big firms as well?Thank you, Patrick Durkin, for highlighting what should have been obvious to everyone - but apparently was not ("Jobs, economic clout keep Crown at the table", October 27).I especially enjoyed your highlighting the contrast between a small business non-compliance and a huge business's outright disregard for law.As a financial planner, I have watched so many long-term businesses fall apart because of this or that non-compliance in areas that would pale to absolutely obscurity compared to this charade.I have known people attempt to kill themselves and in doing so create huge turmoil for those around them - and still for nothing that would reach the levels Crown was able to flaunt.
Financial companies have taken the standard route in dealing with their transgressions.Minimal penalties for the people involved.
Slap on the wrist for the biggest companies, while the smallest cop the brunt of outcomes.It's galling to see this play out so often on the national scene.I'm not condoning a smaller wrong.

I'm simply agreeing with the thrust of your article - at what stage is a corporate entity too big to fail?Just as importantly, what penalties and consequences are genuinely useful in a corporate scenario?
How many of Crown's management went to jail?How many have lost - not just their jobs, but their entire wealth and any access to continuing in their past roles?
Few, would be a generous guess.What better lesson would exist than to see Crown lose its licence?
What has happened to the concept of creative destruction?Again, I can be accused of falling for this or that fallacy, in contrasting my limited experiences with a wider outcome.
So be it.But at some stage, the community has to come to grips with corporate entities and ethics.A tiny, small point of question: who has to pay the newly appointed overseer's costs and income?
Please don't tell me it's the taxpayer.I do appreciate good journalism.
Ethics is whitewashed too often in the public forum.Michael O'HaraEast Perth, WA

documents.result_message: Our detector is highly confident that the text is written entirely by a human.
documents.inputText: Disclosing info won't benefit super membersThe opinion piece by David Gallagher and Peter Swan ("Why making big super disclose its assets is best global practice", October 26) is factually incorrect.It argues that the government's proposal to make industry super funds disclose commercially sensitive valuations of unlisted assets is consistent with global best practice, exemplified by the US Securities Exchange Commission's portfolio holdings disclosure rules. However, the SEC requires institutional investors to disclose only listed assets, not unlisted assets.The main beneficiaries of the government's proposal would be the likes of private equity funds and foreign investors looking to exploit the private information of industry super fund members. The losers would be millions of working Australians who rely on industry super fund trustees to protect and grow their retirement nest eggs.The government has clearly recognised the risks of such disclosures and sought an exemption for the Future Fund from the Freedom of Information Act on the basis it could risk the value of its investment portfolio.Quite rightly, the last thing the Future Fund wants is the investors to whom it might want to sell an asset knowing exactly how much the Future Fund itself thinks that asset is worth. IFM Investors and industry super funds support disclosures that will help members better understand where their retirement savings are invested, and have suggested a range of solutions to the government. To its credit, the government has consulted widely and it is hoped that a balanced outcome is achievable. As an aside, the article describes industry super funds as "union-dominated funds". They are, in fact, jointly governed by employer associations and unions.David NealChief executive, IFM InvestorsMelbourne, VicDoesn't ethics apply to big firms as well?Thank you, Patrick Durkin, for highlighting what should have been obvious to everyone - but apparently was not ("Jobs, economic clout keep Crown at the table", October 27) .I especially enjoyed your highlighting the contrast between a small business non-compliance and a huge business's outright disregard for law.As a financial planner, I have watched so many long-term businesses fall apart because of this or that non-compliance in areas that would pale to absolutely obscurity compared to this charade.I have known people attempt to kill themselves and in doing so create huge turmoil for those around them - and still for nothing that would reach the levels Crown was able to flaunt. Financial companies have taken the standard route in dealing with their transgressions.Minimal penalties for the people involved. Slap on the wrist for the biggest companies, while the smallest cop the brunt of outcomes.It's galling to see this play out so often on the national scene.I'm not condoning a smaller wrong. I'm simply agreeing with the thrust of your article - at what stage is a corporate entity too big to fail?Just as importantly, what penalties and consequences are genuinely useful in a corporate scenario? How many of Crown's management went to jail?How many have lost - not just their jobs, but their entire wealth and any access to continuing in their past roles? Few, would be a generous guess.What better lesson would exist than to see Crown lose its licence? What has happened to the concept of creative destruction?Again, I can be accused of falling for this or that fallacy, in contrasting my limited experiences with a wider outcome. So be it.But at some stage, the community has to come to grips with corporate entities and ethics.A tiny, small point of question: who has to pay the newly appointed overseer's costs and income? Please don't tell me it's the taxpayer.I do appreciate good journalism. Ethics is whitewashed too often in the public forum.Michael O'HaraEast Perth, WA
